summary: Seventeen-year-old Ruby (Emilia Jones) is the sole hearing member of a deaf family -- a CODA, child of deaf adults. Her life revolves around acting as interpreter for her parents (Marlee Matlin, Troy Kotsur) and working on the family's struggling fishing boat every day before school with her father and older brother (Daniel Durant). But when Ruby joins her high school's choir club, she discovers a gift for singing and soon finds herself drawn to her duet partner Miles (Ferdia Walsh-Peelo). Encouraged by her enthusiastic, tough-love choirmaster (Eugenio Derbez) to apply to a prestigious music school, Ruby finds herself torn between the obligations she feels to her family and the pursuit of her own dreams.

Siân Heder brings a powerful story to the screen with her Sundance breakout. Apple's history-making $25 million dollar purchase from the Sundance Film Festival brings together a sensational ensemble and a well-written screenplay. Showcasing stellar performance from its entire cast ‘CODA' is a touching film that shines a light on the deaf community. Adapted from the French film ‘The Bélier Family', Heder's film rectifies one of its predecessor's many faults by casting actual deaf actors in the roles of deaf characters. As well as its record-breaking price tag, ‘CODA' has gone on to win a plethora of awards such as, 3 Academy Awards at the 94th Oscars, including Best Picture, 2 SAG awards and 2 BAFTAs. The film is the first feature with a predominantly deaf cast to win Best Picture, and Troy Kotsur is the first deaf actor to win a BAFTA.

‘Locke & Key' star Emilia Jones stars in the film's lead role, bringing the character of Ruby Rossi to the screen, a Massachusetts teenager who happens to be the only hearing person in her deaf family (brought to life by brilliant performances from Marlee Matlin and Daniel Durant and a sensational performance from Troy Kotsur). Ruby must work to juggle high school, working on her family's fishing boat and her new commitment to the school choir. When singing becomes a passion for Ruby she's faced with the decision to apply for Berklee College of Music; Ruby finds herself at a crossroads – leave her family and follow her dreams or stay in Gloucester, Massachusetts, and continue to work in the family business.

The film features electric performances from its entire cast while giving audiences an insight into a community more-or-less forgotten about by society – showing viewers how, even in a crowded room, deaf people can feel isolated. Troy Kotsur's Oscar, BAFTA and SAG award-winning performance is arguably the standout part of ‘CODA', with his only spoken line being enough to draw audiences to tears. Emilia Jones' performance is equally marvellous, her performances brilliantly show audiences what it's like to be in her position as a CODA (child of deaf adults), acting a both interpreter and daughter at times. ‘CODA' is a film not entirely dissimilar to Darius Marder's 2019 drama ‘Sound of Metal' starring Riz Ahmed and real-life CODA Paul Raci. Both films heavily revolve around deafness and being deaf, and each happened to be nominated for Best Picture, with ‘CODA' going onto win the distinguished accolade.

Despite coming off as a child-friendly coming-of-age drama, ‘CODA' quickly grows on you as the film progresses, turning from a cliché film into an emotional, heart-warming tear-jerker. ‘Pam & Tommy's Paula Huidobro provides the film with pleasant visuals that make ‘CODA' all the more enjoyable to watch. Heder's eloquent screenplay skilfully walks the line between comedy and drama that is thoroughly entertaining and carefully pulls you into its powerful story. The film cleverly balances themes and ideas that some may not be all that familiar with ones that are more known to mainstream/hearing audiences, taking those things and transforming them into a dynamic and feel-good film that you can easily get behind. Emilia Jones also lends her voice to the film's soundtrack, providing vocals for six songs featured throughout the film, including a passionate cover of Joni Mitchell's 1969 song ‘Both Sides Now'.

Siân Heder's Oscar-winning adaptation tells a story that resonates with CODAs across the globe and builds a bridge between deaf and hearing audiences through uplifting storytelling and knockout performances. ‘CODA' tells the tale of a teen torn between two lives as she struggles to make her way in the world. Despite being a formulaic film in which you can easily predict what's going to happen next, Siân Heder manages to create something that greatly succeeds in being a stirring familial affair set to stand the test of time as feel-good crowd pleaser.

There's a lot to like in this movie.  Or there could have been a lot.
The top of that list is - what if they did not 'translated for the audience the signed language? You'd have to figure out what the deaf characters are 'saying.' And I tried it - without the subtitles - and it worked for me. It was like watching a silent movie. It added a lot to the movie - it made it special - a movie about a deaf family and, like them, you had to figure out what people were 'saying' throw their body language. The acting was good enough to do that- all top notch, even if a little over the top. 
But even that great idea would not have saved this movie from mediocrity. The problem is the story line - it's very trite. The problems raised by the plot are not real. There are so many simple solutions to these 'problems' that I couldn't understand why they didn't discover them - these people are deaf but they still are smart. Need a speaking member of the crew on the fishing boat? Hire one. It's not like that is a problem. Oh, but then how will the hearing person deal with the deaf father and son on board the boat? Well, the deaf son/brother meets a girl in a bar and they communicate very well by texting to each other. Sounds like a solution.  You can even turn on the vibrate function so you won't miss any messages. 
The subplot about how the government is ruining the livelihood of the fishermen is just plain ridiculous. And the idea that this family - so poor that Mom worries about a $2 purchase - could afford to start a co-op and rent a warehouse - it's just silly. OK, that's the story and I can accept it. But just don't make it so silly.
Of course, the real story is about how a family copes with a child who is about to leave the nest. Yes, it is hard. And while the family is poor the story throws in a 'rich boy' character to say that while the family in question is poor, they love each other and laugh, as opposed to his rich but sad family. Really? 
Yes, telling the story of a deaf family using deaf actors is a great idea, but please, do it honestly.

A brilliant use of sound dropping away in a music performance scene gives to hearing audience members the most profound moment of empathy in the film; there are other moments, and sequences that hit home in their own way. Emilia Jones' singing voice is something special too, it's not hard to see her career taking a distinctly musical direction from here on out. Ultimately it has more to recommend it than other similar films, and its heart is undoubtedly in a good place. But it also could, and perhaps should, have been more too.

Director Siân Heder's coming of age drama CODA (Child of Deaf Adults) (2021) is a truly moving picture with astoundingly creative filmmaking. Heder's direction feels completely in control and natural. Her ability to balance the coming of age comedy of high school friendship, relationships, choir practice, college applications with musical singing auditions and family drama centered around fishing work and deaf accessibility is incredible. CODA easily earned their nomination for a Best Picture Oscar at The Academy Awards. I hope CODA wins!

Siân Heder's direction is very poignant as she puts you into the shoes of a poor family, further struggling in this Massachusetts fishing community because three of the four of them are deaf. You listen to beautiful music for the singing passages, but it is the unheard pleas and troubles of people who cannot hear that reverberates loudest about CODA. She lets you feel like you're in this quaint and close-knit family dynamic with her intimate dramatic scenes with realistic and grounded conflicts. Heder's heartfelt depiction of how deaf people must live in America also inspires courage with Emilia Jones' fantastic singing abilities and musical journey. I'm so happy to see more lady directors like the bright shining star Siân Heder rise to the forefront of cinema.

Writer Siân Heder's sincere care for the deaf community is self-evident as she empathetically relates viewers to their daily struggles as real people with their own perspectives. Seeing the numerous ways that deaf humans have to communicate with other deaf people and hearing individuals is fascinating and touching. Heder's dialogue feels so interesting as CODA is hilarious with outrageous jokes and devastatingly real with her tumultuous family drama. This story is certainly similar to other coming of age comedies and dramas, but it is entirely unique in its execution. I loved how specific and playful her writing feels. Honestly, Heder should have been nominated for her fearsome direction and inventive script.

English actress, singer, songwriter Emilia Jones is a charming delight as Ruby Rossi in CODA! I found Emilia Jones absolutely gorgeous with a magnetic personality. Her effervescent natural beauty and captivating facial expressions make her dreamy. She has very expressive eyes to act out Ruby's shy natural and hurt feelings. Jones has a subtle grace to her delivery. I am totally blown away by Emilia Jones. Her impressively fast sign language skills are as mind boggling as her powerful singing prowess. I don't even understand how Emilia Jones could be so talented to act with a believable American accent instead of her natural, cute, posh English accent. She simultaneously was acting, signing, and singing in the finale audition! Her shy and dreamy lead actress performance in CODA will remain one of the coming of age genre's finest claims to fame. How Emilia Jones for CODA or Rachel Zegler for West Side Story were not nominated for Best Actress Oscars over Jessica Chastain or Nicole Kidman will forever be lost on me. I cannot wait to see Emilia Jones again.

Trailblazing, American, deaf actress Marlee Matlin is excellent as Ruby's tough and unsympathetic mother Jackie Rossi. She really plays it mean and selfish, before Jackie opens up to her daughter. Matlin is a class act and a brilliant actress and CODA proves her versatility. I do not understand how Marlee Matlin is getting passed up for Best Supporting Actress everywhere as she's as gripping as Troy Kotsur.

Everyone will love groundbreaking, American, deaf actor Troy Kotsur as Ruby's amiable and frustrated fisherman father Frank Rossi. His expressive sign language and hilarious delivery make him so charming and fun. The scene where he touches Ruby's throat to hear how wonderful her singing is really moved me. No wonder he is sweeping Best Supporting Actor all awards season!

Daniel Durant is incredibly nuanced as Ruby's deaf fisherman brother Leo Rossi. I completely understood how his character felt when the other fisherman mocked him for being deaf or when he perceptively understood how Ruby felt about singing. He's really quite remarkable in his own right. The only reason Daniel Durant is not getting more recognition is because he's surrounded by genius actors delivering equally impressive performances. Canadian actress Amy Forsyth has real chemistry with Durant. She is very pretty and funny as Ruby's outgoing friend Gertie.

Mexican actor Eugenio Derbez is a riot as Ruby's encouraging choir teacher Bernardo Villalobos. His energetic charisma, funny delivery, deft piano playing, and skillful singing are all mesmerizing. Ferdia Walsh-Peelo is quite nice and likable as Miles. His singing is pleasant as is his guitar playing, but it is his personable manner that really redeems Miles after his initial standoffish behavior and cruel mistake that hurts poor Ruby's feelings.

Geraud Brisson's swift editing makes CODA's 112 minutes swim by briskly for a pleasant 112 minutes. It feels fast paced with sweet montages of fishing, singing, or hanging out that are quite effective. I love the hard cuts between Ruby having to go from fishing all day to attending school and choir practice that really let you feel how busy and overworked she is constantly. Paula Huidobro's cinematography is gorgeous with all these stunning wide shots of the ocean or the Rossi's family fishing vessel. The medium shots during the conversations and the close-ups of faces are very tender. CODA has a very personal and intimate feel. I loved all the natural scenery from the sea to the quarry and trees.

Diane Lederman's production design is great as you see how poor the Rossi family is supposed to be with their messy house that is essentially a large wooden shack. Paul Richards' art direction focuses on light pouring in naturally through windows and across the boat. I love how bright and vibrant CODA looks. For all the mean viewers and critics bashing CODA, I was actually taken aback by how sleek and creative the craftsmanship is in all aspects of CODA. Set decorators Chris Conroy, Vanessa Knoll, Deborah Kehs, Thyra Heder, Joshua Manning, Mazie Biswell, Christina Bauer, Sara Itkis, Steven Coutts, Christopher Doig, James Giovannucci, Jamie Joseph, Chris Sawtelle, Layla Calo-Fee, Setha Phongsavan, Collin Williams, and Jonathan Langeveld provide quaint set dressing and furnishings for this fishing family. From the house with scattershot posters and plates to the realistic fishing equipment.

Composer Marius de Vries' lovely score for CODA is mesmerizing with uplifting melodies and powerful songwriting. The music chimes in with a pleasant warmth and softness I liked. Sound designers Martin Pinsonnault, Stéphane Bergeron, Paul Col, Alexandra Fehrman, and David Tremblay do more than just create all the ambient noises around CODA's town. Their cutting out sound or fading out noises to simulate what it is like to be deaf is creative genius. Meanwhile, they beautifully and clearly mix Emilia Jones' transcendent vocals. The singing passages sound pristine and Emilia's soft voice sounds all the more divine thanks to their authentic acoustic mixing. CODA has a crisp and up front vocal mix.

Costume designers Brenda Abbandandolo and Courtney Stephens create layered fisherman garments and gear alongside super cute sweaters and plaid shirts for Emilia Jones attending school. Everything she wears feels practical, modern, and something her small town girl Ruby would actually adorn. Juliet Loveland and Krystle Poulin's make-up lets Emilia glow with a natural radiance.

In conclusion, CODA remains one of 2021's finest crafted films and most earnestly entertaining movies.

CODA is about an 18-year-old named Ruby who is the only one in her family of four without a hearing impairment. Her father is a fisherman, and she needs to help her dad with fishing since he can't hear. For example, if he violates a fishing code, the Coast Guard calls him, but he cannot respond because he can't hear the call.  That's when Ruby comes in handy. Ruby's passion is singing. Her dream is to go to the Berklee College of Music. She finds out about a chorus group and joins it, which leads to some conflicts—primarily that her family relies on her, but she also wants to live her life and go to college.

CODA, which stands for "child of deaf adults", is an outstanding film (with many awards and nominations) that is a remake of the 2014 French film, La Famille Bélier. Sian Heder wrote and directed this beautiful adapted screenplay. Not only is this film heartwarming and comical at the same time, but it also lets the audience experience what it is to be deaf to the point of feeling vulnerable by not experiencing the joy of a live concert. My favorite part is when Ruby performs a song on stage with her family watching in the crowd. This is the most interesting and heartwarming scene because when they cut out the audio you get to see the dad's point of view. You really feel what he experiences as a deaf person.

There are many morals to this film, but the main one is that no matter what you suffer from or who you are—or even how you look—we are all humans. We should all be treated equally, and we are each unique in our own way. CODA does have some sexual scenes and foul language.

An incredibly sensitive and thoughtful look at the deaf community, the problems they face in their everyday lives and the person who ends up struck in the middle. The arguments in the film largely take place in near-silence, which is not only realistic, but demonstrates just how good the acting is, as the performers have to express themselves without so much as raising their voices. The story is fairly predictable, with the protagonist bouncing between what she wants to do and what is expected of her, but the writing, acting and direction is enough to make it feel fresh, and for the themes to feel resonant. It sheds light not just on the deaf community, but also the plight of hard-working fishermen and women who break their backs day in and out and yet still get dumped on from those ‘above them.' Their fighting back against their superiors is almost a metaphor for their fighting for societal acceptance, and the film is smart enough not only to show how people have varying reactions to deaf individuals, but that those same individuals are not, by any means, perfect. A lesser filmmaker would have portrayed the deaf family as being innocent angels fighting against an evil world, but we're shown their very humans flaws. Hypocrisy, dishonesty, selfishness etc. These are things that everybody can understand, and presenting the family in a more realistic light makes them more believable. It can be funny and emotional in the same scene, and it hopeful without having to resort to mawkishness. It's a great to see a film about a minority that doesn't condescend or patronise, and isn't afraid to highlight faults wherever they lie. CODA is, simply, a great movie, and I hope it that as many people see it as possible. It honestly, truly deserves it.

Ruby Rossi (Emilia Jones) falls under the category of CODA, a Child Of a Deaf Adult. Her mother (Marlee Matlin) and father (Tony Kotsur) and her older brother (Daniel Durant) are all deaf, and she is the only member of her household with the ability to hear. She's balancing working for her family on their fishing trawler, maintaining good grades in school, and possibly pursuing scholarships to enroll at a music and fine arts college for singing. Ruby's music teacher agrees to train her because he believes in her potential, but Ruby has to worry that her dream is something that cannot be shared with the people she loves most, and how would they all get on without her?

The framework of CODA is familiar to anyone who has watched a coming-of-age story or family drama, but it's the conviction and strength of character and sheer force of empathy that makes this movie a standout film for 2021. It's based upon a 2014 French film, The Family Beller, and follows many of the same beats from other sentimental family dramas about sticking out in your family and society, chasing your dream, often in conflict with your family's expectations, gaining that sense of inner strength and resolve, and mending differences in perspective with hard-fought and well-earned wisdom. It's familiar, but that doesn't mean under the right set of hands that it cannot still be resonant and emotionally gratifying. I do not hold the familiar formula against CODA, even as the family's goal and her personal goal come into direct conflict in sometimes forced manners. That's because the movie does an excellent job of establishing these people as characters, establishing the family dynamic as fraught but loving, and establishing a conflict that is direct and clear as far a major point of separation.

Ruby isn't just the only member of her family who can hear, she's also their vital lifeline to the outside world. She's looked upon as the family interpreter, a position they cannot afford to pay for someone else's services so the duties and responsibilities fall upon her. That's so much pressure to bear for one teenage girl, knowing that she's the link between her family's poverty-treading existence and possibly breaking free into a larger hearing community. She feels ostracized and awkward within her own family and outside of her own family. To the rest of the school, she's that "deaf family girl," and it's remarked that when she began high school she had an accent reminiscent of what deaf people can sound like, a point that her peers cruelly imitate. She worries she will forever be defined by her family's disability even if she doesn't share it. However, within her family, she feels ostracized because she's different. She wonders if her mother wishes that she too were deaf, and during a heartfelt late-night talk, mom actually admits that upon her daughter's birth she did feel disappointment when Ruby had hearing. While she knows sign language and has grown up with these loving figures, she'll still always be the one who's different, the one who hears the insults her family cannot.

The film does a remarkable effort about contextualizing Ruby's fears and frustrations of being held captive in two different worlds, neither feeling fully accepted or whole, and that's why her embarking on a personal dream that her family can never fully appreciate feels so significant. Part of Ruby might feel that singing is selfish, especially if it means limiting her family's upward mobility by eliminating their unpaid interpreter, but it's the thing that makes her most happy, a special gift that her family will be excluded from. There's a wonderful moment toward the end of the movie where Ruby's father asks her to sing to him, and he puts his hands along her shoulders and neck to feel the vibrations, and his awed and tear-stricken face is so moving, as he so desperately wants to indulge too in the beauty of his daughter's voice. While occasionally the film goes overboard pounding these two conflicting paths into forced collision (family vs. self), the movie is personal with its big problems and personal with its big triumphs, making it transcend the trappings of formula.

Writer/director Sian Heder got her start on Orange is the New Black, and that TV series' hallmark has been its enormous sense of empathy for its diverse characters. This is evident in Heder's screenplay and her observational, detail-rich simple storytelling that immerses you in this world, so even while you recognize more familiar made-for-TV plot turns, the genuine authenticity makes the movie feel like its own unique story. Heder's direction is delicate and places the attention squarely on her performers. There is one stylistic move late in the film when Ruby's family comes to her choir recital in support. They look around for cues when to applaud, and their minds wander as they sign about other menial topics like grocery lists, and you understand why once Heder drops you into their perspective. For a minute, the sound disappears, and you're left studying facial expressions for cues like them. While we can imagine being deaf, it's another matter to experience it and try and understand.

The acting is another laudable merit for CODA. I personally want three Oscar nominations for this clan, Jones (Locke & Key) for Best Actress, Matlin (Children of a Lesser God) for Best Supporting Actress, and Kotsur (Wild Prairie Rose) for Best Supporting Actor. Over the course of nine months, Jones learned American Sign Language and how to sing, which is surprising because I would have said she has a natural talent with singing. Her performance, as well as Matlin and Kotsur, feel so real, so nuanced, and so natural, like we've plucked these people from real life and given them this platform. It's the best credit you can give an actor, when they seemingly disappear into the character, and the character feels like a fully breathing, flesh-and-blood person. Even the small supporting roles are well cast, well acted, and contribute to the overall authenticity of the movie. Unlike the 2014 French original movie, all of the deaf members of the family are portrayed by actual deaf actors as well.

CODA was a sensation at the 2021 Sundance Film Festival, with Apple Films buying the rights for $25 million dollars, and it's easy to see why because it's such a satisfying, enriching crowd-pleaser and legit tear-jerker. There were several points that had me tearing up, and then fully crying, because I was so emotionally engaged with the family, their struggles, and their triumphs and outpouring of love. You might be able to see where the movie is headed because its template is familiar and formulaic, but it's the execution, the attention to detail, and the level of observational attention that elevates CODA and makes it so winning and so heartwarming.

She's torn between pursuing her passion for singing and staying with her parents and brother to help them sort out the family's troubled fishing business. At its heart, it's narrative terrain that's been covered a number of times before, albeit with different particulars. That in itself would be fine if it weren't for the trite way in which the material is presented here, a production laden with the aforementioned calculated, derivative qualities that make it ordinary instead of outstanding. The picture also suffers from a screenplay and direction riddled inconsistent character development, left-field plot twists, underdeveloped story threads and over-the-top quirks, making this an often-frustrating watch. The Sundance Film Festival has always been known for giving a great platform to unassuming films by little-known filmmakers. Many of the festival's winners have gone on to win prestigious awards. CODA could be the next candidate in which this scenario occurs. Not only is it one of the biggest crowd-pleasers of the year, but the coming-of-age story gives the sneezy cast of deaf-mute performers a chance to shine.

It is important to mention that CODA is based on the French comedy Do You Understand the Béliers. Whereas in the original work, however, only hearing actors embody the almost exclusively deaf-mute family members, here it is people with the actual affliction. At the latest since Sound of Metal showed this fascinating group in such a grandiose way, deaf-muteness in films has been on everyone's lips. Director Sian Heder wraps this concept in a film reminiscent of coming-of-age stories like Lady Bird and Juno. The youngest member of the family, Ruby, is the only hearing one in her family and helps her loved ones make ends meet as a translator in a less tolerant society. The family owns a fishing business, into which several obstacles get in the way as the plot unfolds. But that is not the main story. Rather, the film is told through Ruby's eyes and accompanies her as she is torn between staying true to her family or pursuing her dream as a singer. 19-year-old Emilia Jones plays this character as authentically and adolescently as possible, and you buy into her almost impossible situation, but one that seems so remote from our point of view. The best moments in CODA occur when she shares emotional dialogue with her parents and brother. Although they only gesture with sign language, you follow the conversation as if it were the spoken word we are used to. This is thanks to the great performances of Oscar winner Marlee Matlin, Troy Kotsur and Laniel Durant. They seem very bizarre and different at first, but it becomes increasingly clear that they too have normal concerns and needs apart from their deafness. Eugenio Derbez, as Ruby's mentor and singing teacher, is also a constant in the protagonist's life that we wish we had.

Out the back, CODA lives up to all the hype as a crowd pleaser. Some scenes press hard on the tear gland and are carried by great sung musical accompaniment. Before that, however, the film takes almost half the time to finally get going. This is detrimental to the film because the plot lost me a little after the long delay. One should not expect surprises anyway. The film follows a classic pattern, but the predictability does it little harm. Rather, the fact that the family conflict built up in the first half never fully unfolds. Only between brother and sister is there a reckoning, but this is not really pursued. In retrospect, however, this is forgotten, as Heder knows how to rely on elements towards the end that simply appeal to filmgoers. I fell for that too and that is the reason why I enjoyed CODA so much in the end. Viewed as a whole, however, the film has obvious weaknesses, which is why I cannot rank it among the top tier coming-of-age stories.

High school crossroads.  So this is about a teenage girl (Emilia Jones).  Her entire family is deaf, and she is the only one who can hear.  She has a decision looming in her near future: does she pursue her musical abilities in post-secondary education, or does she abandon that by the wayside to help support the family fishing business?  Now this one caught my eye on Apple TV+ because the trailers looked intriguing.  Deaf people get so little representation in television and film, so I added this to my watchlist to check out at my earliest opportunity.  I'm glad that I did because this is one of the stronger films of the year.  The only thing I had heard about this beforehand was how it has scenes that will rip your heart out.  While that is mostly what the third act consists of, all of that would have been for naught if they didn't lay the groundwork in advance.  They take the time to make you like and connect with this family, and you can relate because this girl has normal teenage problems on top of her family's condition.  She's got a bit of stage freight, she gets lightly bullied, she has trouble talking to the boy she's crushing on, and she gets embarrassed by her parents.  All members of this family turn in impressive performances through ASL, but I think that Emilia Jones shines brightest.  She's a talented little actress who is cast age-appropriately as a high schooler and not only that, she has some pipes on her as well.  It reminded me in a way of Florence Foster Jenkins.  Not that she sings poorly, mind you, but she has to vary her talent as she learns the craft.  That is a difficult feat to pull off when you clearly already know your vocal range and abilities.  The story to this isn't anything new.  This is a coming-of-age tale at its core, and it has all of the moments that you would expect to see in that kind of story.  CODA gets by on the strengths of its performances, and I would be surprised to see a dry eye in the room if I watched this in a group setting.  My only real complaint is that the choir teacher played by Eugenio Derbez.  He felt a bit cartoony at times, and he went over the top in the same way that Taika Waititi has in the past to varying degrees of success.  I don't think it quite fit the tone at times, but it wasn't enough to spoil it for me.  This is a tear-jerker, and I feel that it successfully earned all of the waterworks that it got out of me.

Sian Heder's "CODA" is an empowering, heartbreaking and inspirational family drama that suggests disabled casting marks positive steps in the right direction for onscreen deaf representation. With her second feature, writer/director Sian Heder gives a voice to voiceless communities by creating compassionate portrait of a tighknit deaf family through disabled casting. It's the filmmaker's first attempt to humanize the hardships experienced by hearing children of deaf families, but she pulls it off effectively. Using spellbinding cinematography, Heder draws viewers into struggles faced by a hearing teen obligated to provide for her deaf family. Heder's decision to shoot the movie in a smalltown setting is risky, but it works immensely. It lends a sense of realism and authenticity to the movie missing from the original French film, making it feel like a lived-in place. Heder showcases immense control over sound design, editing techniques and music, using these elements to create an unforgettable cinematic experience. Heder's screenplay is also sensational, and expertly uses subtle sign-language to establish the compassionate bond between a close-knit deaf family. It's hard to not praise phenomenal performances from cast. Emilia Jones delivers a star-making performance as Ruby Rossi. With mesmerizing expressions, she conveys angst, compassion and lifelong resentments of a hearing  teenager that strives to make ends meet for her financially needy deaf family. The supporting cast is sensational and also worthy of recognition. Heder's decision to cast hard-of-hearing actors pays off tremendously. Troy Kotsur, in particular, leaves a lasting impression as Ruby's affectionate patriarch through meaningful gestures.   Although "CODA"  is undeniably an unforgettable family drama, ultimately it isn't a flawless film. If there's a minor drawback to the movie, it's slightly undermined by an unnecessary teen romance subplot that distracts from the deaf family's conflict. Nevertheless, fans of coming-of-age dramas will definitely enjoy "CODA" and so will movie-goers seeking meaningful entertainment. If Cinema has power to give voice to voiceless communities, it's time Hollywood honored deaf communities by giving them a loud rather than quiet place in an industry where they can peacefully chase dreams even when luck may not always be in their destinies.

Sian Heder's English remake of the French film 'La Famille Belier' will feel very familiar to anyone who has seen Glee or any coming-of-age movie where the central character is torn between family and pursuing his/her personal dream. Solidly and beautifully directed, with a tastefully appropriate, though a little on-the-nose, soundtrack; the stand out here is the winsome performance by British newcomer Emilia Jones who, as Ruby, the only hearing member in a deaf family whose ironically constructed passion is singing, convincingly plays American and proves a deft hand in ASL. Learning from the mistake made by the French original, the deaf family members here are played by deaf actors and Troy Kotsur, Daniel Durant and Oscar winner Marlee Matlin's likeable portrayal of the close-knit and often excessively honest (and horny) Rossi family is the only unconventional element in a fairly conventional film. Essentially, there are three intertwined stories that will be neatly and predictably resolved by the end of the film, involving Ruby's crush on Miles (an unrecognisable Ferdia Walsh-Peelo from Sing Street); the family's struggling fishing business that sees the previously reclusive family opening up to others; and that difficult choice between family obligations and going to music college, under the tutelage of her Mexican music teacher, a funny and slightly flamboyant turn from Eugenio Derbez. Normally, the deaf element would constitute a fresh distinctive angle but coming so soon after the amazing Sound of Metal, even that's now been done and done better, though comparisons between the two may not be entirely fair. However, judged as the crowd-pleaser that it clearly aims to be, its wholesomeness and positivity is infectious and undeniable, even if the rom-com tropes and contrived conflicts that get resolved far too easily make this film feel too safe and sometimes, corny even.

"CODA" is the kind of feel-good story that Hollywood used to make. The big studios, of course, can't be bothered these days with much of anything that isn't a sequel, a reboot, and/or based on a comic book. So "CODA" is a modest-budget independent film, though one lucky enough to attract the attention of Apple TV+ at the Sundance Film Festival. This remake of a 2014 French film is set in Gloucester, Massachusetts, a fishing town north of Boston. It stars Emilia Jones, a wonderful actress I had never seen before, as Ruby, a teenager who dreams of singing but is held back by the fact that her mother, father, and brother, who are all deaf, are dependent upon her to keep the family fishing business afloat. Marlee Matlin, 35 years past her Oscar-winning performance in "Children of a Lesser God," plays Ruby's mother with warmth and humor and may find herself back in the gold derby again in the supporting contest. And she might be joined at the Oscar party by the well known (at least in Mexico and among Spanish-speaking audiences in the U.S.) Eugenio Derbez, who brings some nice layers to his role as the tough but inspirational music teacher who encourages Ruby to pursue her dreams. The entire film gives off a lovely glow that only the most churlish out there will resist. No grandstanding political statements being crammed down the audience's collective throats,; just good storytelling. Bravo!

An Apple+ Original about a high school student who was the only hearing person in her family. 

I already love the movie when it started out. There were many funny and clever jokes mostly from the main character's deaf parents that showed the tight relationship in the family. I was consistently entertained with what our main character had to go through because she was the only hearing person in her family.

This led to the main conflict for our main character. The struggle between family responsibilities and one's hope and dream was a familiar theme that is explored many times before. However, the story created a new and unique situation that had me sympathized with not our main character, but also her family members. The family dynamics worked so well that the situation even more conflicting.

Still, the movie had many sweet moments. The audition scene near the end was beautiful and got me emotional there. Also, Emilia Jones, who played the main girl Ruby, had a beautiful voice, and I loved every scene where she sang. 

As for problems, the progression was definitely a bit formulaic, but it didn't bother me much at all.

Overall, a sweet, beautiful, and unique slice of life/coming of age story. 9/10
